[[Nankai University]] |prizes = {{Plainlist| * [[Chauvenet Prize]] (1970) * [[National Medal of Science]] (1975) * [[Wolf Prize]] (1983) * [[Lobachevsky Medal]] (2002) * [[Shaw Prize]] (2004) * [[Fellow of the Royal Society|FRS]]{{Cite journal |doi = 10.1098/rsbm.2014.0018 |year = 2014 |title = Shiing-Shen Chern 28 October 1911 — 3 December 2004 |journal = [[Biographical Memoirs of Fellows of the Royal Society]] |author = Nigel Hitchin |authorlink = Nigel Hitchin}}}} |module = {{Chinese |child = yes |t = 陳省身 |s = 陈省身 |p = Chén Xǐngshēn |w = Ch'en Hsing-shen |gr = Chern Shiing-Shen }} }} '''Shiing-Shen Chern''' ({{IPAc-en|tʃ|ɜr|n}}; {{zh|c=陳省身|p=Chén Xǐngshēn}}, {{IPA-cmn|tʂʰən.ɕiŋ.ʂən|lang}}; October 26, 1911 – December 3, 2004) was a Chinese-American [[mathematician]] who made fundamental contributions to [[differential geometry]] and [[topology]]. He was widely regarded as a leader in [[geometry]] and one of the greatest mathematicians of the twentieth century, winning numerous awards and recognition including the [[Wolf Prize in Mathematics|Wolf Prize]] and the inaugural [[Shaw Prize]].{{Cite web|url=http://www-history.mcs.st-and.ac.uk/Biographies/Chern.html|title=Chern biography|website=www-history.mcs.st-and.ac.uk|access-date=2017-01-16}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.berkeley.edu/news/media/releases/2004/12/06_chern.shtml|title=12.06.2004 - Renowned mathematician Shiing-Shen Chern, who revitalized the study of geometry, has died at 93 in Tianjin, China|website=www.berkeley.edu|access-date=2017-01-16}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2004/12/07/world/asia/shiingshen-chern-93-innovator-in-new-geometry-dies.html|title=Shiing-Shen Chern, 93, Innovator in New Geometry, Dies|last=Chang|first=Kenneth|date=2004-12-07|newspaper=The New York Times|issn=0362-4331|access-date=2017-01-16}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.ams.org/notices/199807/chern.pdf|title=Interview with Shiing Shen Chern|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=|access-date=}}{{Cite web|url=https://rd.springer.com/article/10.1007/s00025-011-0196-8|title=Shiing-Shen Chern’s Centenary|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=|access-date=}} Shiing-Shen Chern spent nearly a decade at the [[University of Chicago]] before moving to [[University of California, Berkeley]], where he co-founded the world-renowned [[Mathematical Sciences Research Institute]] in 1982 and was the institute's founding director.{{Cite web|url=http://www.msri.org/web/msri/about-msri/history|title=MSRI|last=MSRI|website=www.msri.org|access-date=2017-01-16}} In memory of Shiing-Shen Chern, the [[International Mathematical Union]] established the [[Chern Medal]] in 2010 to recognize "an individual whose accomplishments warrant the highest level of recognition for outstanding achievements in the field of mathematics".{{Cite web|url=http://www.mathunion.org/general/prizes/chern/details/|title=International Mathematical Union (IMU): Details|last=the_technician|website=www.mathunion.org|access-date=2017-01-16|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100825071850/http://www.mathunion.org/general/prizes/chern/details|archivedate=August 25, 2010|df=mdy-all}} == Biography == === Early years in China === Chern was born in Xiushui County ([[:zh:秀水縣|秀水縣]]), [[Jiaxing]], in [[Zhejiang]] province. The year after his birth, China changed its regime from the [[Qing Dynasty]] to the [[Republic of China (1912–49)|Republic of China]]. He graduated from Xiushui Middle School (秀水中學) and subsequently moved to [[Tianjin]] in 1922 to accompany his father. In 1926, after spending four years in Tianjin, Chern graduated from Fulun High School ([[:zh:扶輪中學|扶輪中學]]).{{cite web |url=http://www.jiaxing.gov.cn/art/2008/10/28/art_93_1125.html |title=Shiing-Shen Chern |publisher=Jiaxing Culture |accessdate=Aug 22, 2010 |language=zh |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110725045157/http://www.jiaxing.gov.cn/art/2008/10/28/art_93_1125.html |archivedate=July 25, 2011 |df=mdy-all }} At age 15, Chern entered the Faculty of Sciences of the [[Nankai University]] in Tianjin, but had problems at the laboratory, so he studied mathematics, instead.{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/41497065|title=Math and mathematicians : the history of math discoveries around the world|last=Bruno|first=Leonard C.|date=2003|origyear=1999|publisher=U X L|others=Baker, Lawrence W.|year=|isbn=0787638137|location=Detroit, Mich.|pages=72|oclc=41497065}} Chern graduated with a Bachelor of Science degree in 1930. At Nankai, Chern's mentor was mathematician [[Jiang Lifu]], and Chern was also heavily influenced by the physicist [[Rao Yutai]], considered to be one of the founding fathers of modern Chinese [[Informatics (academic field)|informatics]]. Chern went to [[Beiping]] (now Beijing) to work at the [[Tsinghua University]] Department of Mathematics as a teaching assistant. At the same time he also registered at Tsinghua Graduate School as a student. He studied [[projective differential geometry]] under [[Sun Guangyuan]], a [[University of Chicago]]-trained geometer and [[logician]] who was also from Zhejiang. Sun is another mentor of Chern who is considered a founder of modern Chinese mathematics. In 1932, Chern published his first research article in the Tsing Hua University Journal. In the summer of 1934, Chern graduated from Tsinghua with a master's degree, the first ever master's degree in mathematics issued in China. [[Yang Chen-Ning]]'s father—[[Yang Ko-Chuen]], another Chicago-trained professor at Tsinghua, but specialising in [[algebra]], also taught Chern. At the same time, Chern was Chen-Ning Yang's teacher of undergraduate maths at Tsinghua. At Tsinghua, [[Hua Luogeng]], also a mathematician, was Chern's colleague and roommate. In 1932, [[Wilhelm Blaschke]] from the University of Hamburg visited Tsinghua and was impressed by Chern and his research.{{cite book|title=A mathematician and his mathematical work: selected papers of S. S. Chern|editor=Chern, S. S.|editor2=Tian, G.|editor3=Li, Peter|year=1996|pages=48–49|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=uOfSa0sfJr0C&pg=PA48}} === In Europe === In 1934, Chern received a scholarship to study in the United States, but he wanted to study under well-known geometer Wilhelm Blaschke. Co-funded by Tsing Hua and the Chinese Foundation of Culture and Education, Chern went to continue his study in mathematics in Germany with a scholarship. Chern studied at the [[University of Hamburg]] and worked under Blaschke's guidance first on the geometry of webs then on the Cartan-[[Erich Kähler|Kähler]] theory. He obtained his ''Dr. rer.nat.'' (''[[Doctor of Science]]'', which is equivalent to PhD) degree in February, 1936. Blaschke recommended Chern to study in Paris. It was at this time that he had to choose between the career of algebra in Germany under [[Emil Artin]], and the career of geometry in France under [[Élie Cartan|Élie-Joseph Cartan]]. Chern was tempted by what he called the "organizational beauty" of Emil Artin's algebra, but in the end, he decided to go to France in September 1936.{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/41497065|title=Math and mathematicians : the history of math discoveries around the world|last=Bruno|first=Leonard C.|date=2003|origyear=1999|publisher=U X L|others=Baker, Lawrence W.|year=|isbn=0787638137|location=Detroit, Mich.|pages=73|oclc=41497065}} He spent one year at the [[Sorbonne]] in Paris. In August 1936, Chern watched the [[1936 Summer Olympics|Summer Olympics]] in Berlin together with [[Hua Luogeng]] who paid Chern a brief visit. During that time, Hua was studying at the University of Cambridge in Britain. In the summer of 1937, Chern accepted the invitation of Tsing Hua's University and returned to China. He was promoted to professor of mathematics at Tsing Hua. However, in August, the [[Marco Polo Bridge Incident]] (near Beijing) happened and the [[Second Sino-Japanese War]] started, Tsing Hua was forced to move away from Beijing to west China.{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/41497065|title=Math and mathematicians : the history of math discoveries around the world|last=Bruno|first=Leonard C.|date=2003|origyear=1999|publisher=U X L|others=Baker, Lawrence W.|year=|isbn=0787638137|location=Detroit, Mich.|pages=74|oclc=41497065}} Three universities including Peking University, Tsing Hua, and Nankai formed the [[National Southwestern Associated University]] (NSAU), and relocated to [[Kunming]], Yunnan province. Chern never reached Beijing. In the same year, [[Hua Luogeng]] was promoted to professor of mathematics at Tsinghua. In 1939, Chern married Shih-Ning Cheng, and the couple had two children by the names of Paul and May. === Short stay in the United States === In July 1943, Chern went to the United States, and worked at the [[Institute for Advanced Study]] (IAS) in [[Princeton, New Jersey|Princeton]] on [[characteristic class]]es in differential geometry. Shortly afterwards, he was invited by [[Solomon Lefschetz]] to be an editor of ''[[Annals of Mathematics]]''. === First return to China === Chern returned to Shanghai in 1945 to help found the Institute of Mathematics of the [[Academia Sinica]], which was later moved to [[Nanking]] (then-capital of the Republic of China). Chern was the acting president of the institute. [[Wu Wenjun]] was Chern's graduate student at the institute. In 1948, Chern was elected one of the first academicians of the Academia Sinica. He was the youngest academician elected (at age 37). === The United States === By the end of 1948, Chern returned to the United States because of the [[Chinese Civil War]]. He then returned to the IAS. In 1949, Chern became professor of mathematics at the [[University of Chicago]]. Coincidentally, [[Ernest Preston Lane]], former Chair at UChicago Department of Mathematics, was the doctoral advisor of Chern's undergraduate mentor at Tsinghua—[[Sun Guangyuan]]. Chern moved to the [[University of California, Berkeley]], in 1960. He worked and stayed there until he became an emeritus professor in 1979.{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/41497065|title=Math and mathematicians : the history of math discoveries around the world|last=Bruno|first=Leonard C.|date=2003|origyear=1999|publisher=U X L|others=Baker, Lawrence W.|year=|isbn=0787638137|location=Detroit, Mich.|pages=|oclc=41497065}} In 1961, Chern became a naturalized citizen of the United States. In the same year, he was elected member of the [[United States National Academy of Sciences]].{{cite web |url = http://www.berkeley.edu/news/media/releases/2004/12/06_chern.shtml |title = Renowned mathematician Shiing-Shen Chern, who revitalized the study of geometry, has died at 93 in Tianjin, China |format=shtml |date = December 6, 2004 |author = Robert Sanders, Media Relations |publisher = [[University of California, Berkeley|UC, Berkeley]] |accessdate = Aug 22, 2010}} In 1964, Chern was a vice-president of [[American Mathematical Society]] (AMS). Chern retired from Berkeley in 1981. He founded the [[Mathematical Sciences Research Institute]] (MSRI) in 1981 and served as the director until 1984. Afterward he became the honorary director of the institute. MSRI now is one of the largest and most prominent mathematical institutes in the world. [[Shing-Tung Yau]] was one of his PhD students during this period. === Short visits to China === The [[Shanghai Communiqué]] was issued by the United States and the People's Republic of China on February 27, 1972. The relationship between these two nations started to normalise, and American citizens were allowed to visit P.R.China. In September 1972, Chern visited Beijing with his wife. During this period of time, Chern visited China 25 times, of which 14 were to his home province Zhejiang. Chern founded the Nankai Institute for Mathematics (NKIM) at his alma mater Nankai in Tianjin. The institute was formally established in 1984 and fully opened in October 17, 1985. NKIM was renamed the [[Chern Institute of Mathematics]] in 2004 after Chern's death. === Final years and death === Based on Chern's advice, a mathematical research center was established in [[Taipei]], Taiwan, whose co-operational partners are [[National Taiwan University]], [[National Tsing Hua University]] and the Sinica Academia Institute of Mathematics.{{cite web |url = http://www.mathland.idv.tw/history/chen.html |title=陳省身 (Shiing-Shen Chern) |publisher=mathland.idv.tw |accessdate=Aug 22, 2010 |language=zh}} Chern was also a director and advisor of the [[Center of Mathematical Sciences, Zhejiang University|Center of Mathematical Sciences at Zhejiang University]] in [[Hangzhou]], Zhejiang. From 2000 to his death, Chern lived in Tianjin, China. Chern died of heart failure at his home in Tianjin in 2004 at age 93. ==Research== Chern's work extends over all the classic fields of differential geometry. It includes areas currently fashionable (the [[Chern–Simons theory]] arising from a 1974 paper written jointly with [[James Harris Simons|Jim Simons]]), perennial (the [[Chern–Weil theory]] linking [[curvature]] invariants to [[characteristic class]]es from 1944, after the [[Carl B. Allendoerfer|Allendoerfer]]–[[André Weil|Weil]] paper of 1943 on the [[Gauss–Bonnet theorem]]), the foundational ([[Chern class]]es), and some areas such as [[projective differential geometry]] and [[web (mathematics)|web]]s that have a lower profile. He published results in [[integral geometry]], [[value distribution theory of holomorphic functions]], and [[minimal submanifold]]s. He was a follower of [[Élie Cartan]], working on the '[[theory of equivalence]]' in his time in China from 1937 to 1943, in relative isolation. In 1954 he published his own treatment of the [[pseudogroup]] problem that is in effect the touchstone of Cartan's geometric theory. He used the [[moving frame]] method with success only matched by its inventor; he preferred in [[complex manifold]] theory to stay with the geometry, rather than follow the [[potential theory]]. Indeed, one of his books is entitled "Complex Manifolds without Potential Theory". In the last years of his life, he advocated the study of [[Finsler geometry]], writing several books and articles on the subject. == Honors and awards == Chern received numerous honors and awards in his life, including: * 1970, [[Chauvenet Prize]], of the Mathematical Association of America; * 1975, [[National Medal of Science]][https://www.nsf.gov/od/nms/recip_details.cfm?recip_id=75 National Science Foundation – The President's National Medal of Science] * 1982, [[Humboldt Prize]], Germany; * 1983, [[Leroy P. Steele Prize]], of the American Mathematical Society; * 1984, [[Wolf Prize in Mathematics]], Israel; * 2002, [[Lobachevsky Medal]]; * 2004 May, [[Shaw Prize]] in mathematical sciences, Hong Kong;{{cite journal|author=Bryant, Robert|authorlink=Robert Bryant (mathematician)|author2=Freed, Dan|authorlink2=Dan Freed|title=Obituary: Shiing-Shen Chern|journal=Physics Today|date=January 2006|volume=59|issue=1|pages=70–72|url=http://scitation.aip.org/content/aip/magazine/physicstoday/article/59/1/10.1063/1.2180187|doi=10.1063/1.2180187}} * 1948, Academician, [[Academia Sinica]]; * 1950, Honorary Member, [[Indian Mathematical Society]]; * 1961, Member, [[United States National Academy of Sciences]]; * 1963, Fellow, [[American Academy of Arts and Sciences]]; * 1971, Corresponding Member, [[Brazilian Academy of Sciences]]; * 1983, Associate Founding Fellow, [[TWAS]]; * 1985, Foreign Fellow, [[Royal Society of London]], UK; * 1986, Honorary Fellow, [[London Mathematical Society]], UK; * 1986, Corresponding Member, Academia Peloritana, Messina, Sicily; * 1987, Honorary Life Member, [[New York Academy of Sciences]]; * 1989, Foreign Member, [[Accademia dei Lincei]], Italy; * 1989, Foreign Member, [[French Academy of Sciences|Académie des sciences]], France; * 1989, Member, [[American Philosophical Society]]; * 1994, Foreign Member, [[Chinese Academy of Sciences]]. Chern was given a number of honorary degrees, including from The [[Chinese University of Hong Kong]] (LL.D. 1969), [[University of Chicago]] (D.Sc. 1969), [[ETH Zurich]] (Dr.Math. 1982), [[SUNY Stony Brook]] (D.Sc. 1985), [[Berlin Institute of Technology|TU Berlin]] (Dr.Math. 1986), his alma mater [[University of Hamburg|Hamburg]] (D.Sc. 1971) and [[Nankai University|Nankai]] (honorary doctorate, 1985), etc. Chern was also granted numerous [[Honorary title (academic)|honorary professorship]]s, including at [[Peking University]] (Beijing, 1978), his alma mater Nankai ([[Tianjin]], 1978), Chinese Academy of Sciences Institute of Systems Science (Beijing, 1980), [[Jinan University]] ([[Guangzhou]], 1980), Chinese Academy of Sciences Graduate School (1984), [[Nanjing University]] (Nanjing, 1985), [[East China Normal University]] (Shanghai, 1985), [[University of Science and Technology of China|USTC]] ([[Hefei]], 1985), [[Beijing Normal University]] (1985), [[Zhejiang University]] ([[Hangzhou]], 1985), [[Hangzhou University]] (1986, the university was merged into Zhejiang University in 1998), [[Fudan University]] (Shanghai, 1986), [[Shanghai University of Technology]] (1986, the university was merged to establish [[Shanghai University]] in 1994), [[Tianjin University]] (1987), [[Tohoku University]] ([[Sendai]], Japan, 1987), etc. ==Publication== *Shiing Shen Chern, Topics in Differential Geometry, Princeton 1951 *Shiing Shen Chern Differential Manifolds 1953 University of Chicago *Shiing Shen Chern, Complex Manifolds University of Chicago, 1956 *Shiing Shen Chern:Complex manifolds without potential theory *Shiing Shen Chern, Minimal Sumanifolds in a Riemannian Manifold University of Kansas 1968 *Bao, David Dai-Wai; Chern, Shiing-Shen; Shen, Zhongmin [http://www.ams.org/books/conm/196/ Finsler Geometry] *Zhongmin Shen, Shiing-shen Chern, Riemann Finsler Geometry *Shiing Shen Chern, Selected Papers, Vol I-IV, Springer ===Namesake=== * The [[asteroid]] [[29552 Chern]] is named after him; * The [[Chern Medal]], of the [[International Mathematical Union]] (IMU);{{cite web |url=http://www.icm2010.org.in/imu-prizes |title=The IMU Prizes |publisher=[[International Mathematical Union]] (IMU) |accessdate=Aug 22, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100818015117/http://www.icm2010.org.in/imu-prizes |archivedate=August 18, 2010 |df=mdy-all }} * The Shiing-Shen Chern Prize (陳省身獎), of the Association of Chinese Mathematicians; * The Chern Institute of Mathematics at [[Nankai University]], Tianjin, China; * The Chern Lectures, and the'' Shiing-Shen Chern Chair in Mathematics'', both at the Department of Mathematics, [[UC Berkeley]].{{cite web |url=http://math.berkeley.edu/events_series_chern.html |title=The Chern Lectures |publisher=[[UC Berkeley]] Department of Mathematics |accessdate=Aug 22, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110607082120/http://math.berkeley.edu/events_series_chern.html |archivedate=June 7, 2011 |df=mdy-all }} ==Family== His wife, Shih-ning Cheng ({{zh|c=鄭士寧|p=Zheng Shining}}), whom he married in 1939, died in 2000. He also had a daughter, May Chu ({{zh|c=陳璞|p=Chen Pu}}), wife of the physicist [[Chu Ching-wu]], and a son named Paul ({{zh|陳伯龍|p=Chen Bolong}}). ==Transliteration and pronunciation== Chern's surname is a common Chinese surname which is now usually spelt [[Chen (surname)|Chen]]. The unusual spelling "Chern" is a [[transliteration]] in the old [[Gwoyeu Romatzyh]] (GR) [[romanization]] for [[Mandarin Chinese]] used in the early twentieth-century China. It uses special spelling rules to indicate different tones of Mandarin, which is a [[tonal language]] with four tones. The silent ''r'' in "Chern" indicates a [[Standard Mandarin#Tones|second-tone]] syllable, written "Chén" in [[pinyin]] but in practice often written by non-Chinese without the tonal mark. In GR the spelling of his given name "Shiing-Shen" indicates a third tone for ''Shiing'' and a first tone for ''Shen'', which are equivalent to the syllables "Xǐngshēn" in [[pinyin]]. In English, Chern pronounced his name "Churn" ({{IPAc-en|tʃ|ɜr|n}}), and this pronunciation is now universally accepted among English-speaking mathematicians and physicists. == See also == {{Portal|Mathematics|China|Asian American|Biography}} *[[Chern classes]] *[[Chern–Gauss–Bonnet theorem]] *[[Chern–Simons theory]] *[[Chern–Simons form]] *[[Chern–Weil theory]] *[[Chern–Weil homomorphism]] == References == {{Reflist|colwidth=30em}} == External links == {{commons cat}} {{wikiquote}} * [http://www.berkeley.edu/news/media/releases/2004/12/06_chern.shtml UC Berkeley obituary] * [http://www.ams.org/notices/199807/chern.pdf 1998 interview in ''Notices of the American Mathematical Society''] * {{MathGenealogy |id = 6424}} * {{MacTutor Biography |id = Chern}} * [http://www.ams.org/bull/2009-46-02/S0273-0979-08-01219-6/home.html Shiing-shen Chern: 1911–2004] by H. Wu, biography and overview of mathematical work. * {{Citation |title = Shiing-Shen Chern (1911–2004) |journal = Notices of the American Mathematical Society |volume = 58 |issue = 9 |pages = 1226–1249 |publisher = American Mathematical Society |location = Providence, Rhode Island |date = October 2011 |url = http://www.ams.org/notices/201109/rtx110901226p.pdf |format = PDF}} {{Infobox magazine | image_file = The New Atlantis Cover - Summer 2012.jpg | editor = Ari Schulman | discipline = | peer-reviewed = | language = [[English language|English]] | former_names = | abbreviation = | publisher = [[The Center for the Study of Technology and Society]], [[Ethics and Public Policy Center|The Ethics and Public Policy Center]] | based = [[Washington, D.C.]] | frequency = Quarterly | founded = {{start date|2003}} | website = {{URL|http://www.thenewatlantis.com}} | OCLC = 56518547 | CODEN = | ISSN = 1543-1215 | eISSN = 1555-5569 }} '''''The New Atlantis''''', founded in 2003, is a quarterly journal about the social, ethical, political, and policy dimensions of modern [[science]] and [[technology]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.reason.com/blog/show/101563.html|title=Welcome to The New Atlantis|work=Reason|date=May 5, 2003|accessdate=December 6, 2012}}</ref> The journal is published in Washington, D.C. by the Center for the Study of Technology and Society.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tecsoc.org/about/|title=The Center for the Study of Technology and Society — About|website=The Center for the Study of Technology and Society|accessdate=September 25, 2018}}</ref> The New Atlantis was founded by the [[social conservative]] advocacy group the [[Ethics and Public Policy Center]]. It is edited by Ari Schulman, having previously been edited by co-founders Eric Cohen and Adam Keiper.
The journal’s name is taken from [[Francis Bacon]]’s utopian novella ''[[New Atlantis]]'', which the journal’s editors describe as a "fable of a society living with the benefits and challenges of advanced science and technology."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thenewatlantis.com/about/why-we-are-called-the-new-atlantis|title=Why We Are Called ''The New Atlantis''|accessdate=December 6, 2012}}</ref> An editorial in the inaugural issue states that the aim of the journal is "to help us avoid the extremes of euphoria and despair that new technologies too often arouse; and to help us judge when mobilizing our technological prowess is sensible or necessary, and when the preservation of things that count requires limiting the kinds of technological power that would lessen, cheapen, or ultimately destroy us."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thenewatlantis.com/publications/the-new-politics-of-technology|title=The New Politics of Technology|last=Cohen|first=Eric|work=The New Atlantis |date=Spring 2003}}</ref> Writing for ''[[National Review]]'', editor Adam Keiper described ''The New Atlantis'' as being written from a "particularly American and [[conservative]] way of thinking about both the blessings and the burdens of modern science and technology."<ref>{{cite news|last= Keiper|first=Adam|title=The New Atlantis Turns Ten|url=http://www.nationalreview.com/corner/348857/new-atlantis-turns-ten-adam-keiper|newspaper=The Corner|date=May 29, 2003}}</ref> ''New Atlantis'' authors and bioethicists publishing in other journals have also similarly referred to ''The New Atlantis'' as being written from a social conservative stance which utilizes religion.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.thenewatlantis.com/publications/the-paradox-of-conservative-bioethics | title=The Paradox of Conservative Bioethics}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.thenewatlantis.com/publications/st-francis-christian-love-and-the-biotechnological-future | title=St. Francis, Christian Love, and the Biotechnological Future}}</ref><ref name="MIT"/><ref name="Hastings"/>
==Subjects== ''The New Atlantis'' tends to publish views in favor of technological innovation but wary of certain avenues of development. For example, the journal has generally advocated nuclear energy;<ref>{{cite web|title=Nuclear Energy|url=http://www.thenewatlantis.com/publications/topic/nuclear-energy|accessdate=2012-12-06}}</ref> space exploration and development through public-private partnerships,<ref>{{cite web|last=Simberg|first=Rand|title=In Search of a Conservative Space Policy|url=http://www.thenewatlantis.com/publications/in-search-of-a-conservative-space-policy|work=The New Atlantis|date=Fall 2010}}</ref> including manned missions to Mars;<ref>{{cite web|last=Zubrin|first=Robert|title=The Human Explorer|url=http://www.thenewatlantis.com/publications/the-human-explorer|work=The New Atlantis|date=Winter 2004}}</ref> biofuels;<ref>{{cite web|title=Biofuels|url=http://www.thenewatlantis.com/publications/topic/biofuels|accessdate=December 6, 2012}}</ref> and genetically modified foods.<ref>{{cite web|last=Adler|first=Jonathan|title=How Not to Label Biotech Foods|url=http://www.thenewatlantis.com/publications/how-not-to-label-biotech-foods|publisher=The New Atlantis|date=Summer 2012}}</ref> But it has expressed ambivalent or critical views about developments in [[synthetic biology]]<ref>{{cite web|title=Synthetic biology|url=http://www.thenewatlantis.com/publications/topic/synthetic-biology|accessdate=December 6, 2012}}</ref> and military technologies like [[Unmanned combat aerial vehicle|drones]],<ref>{{cite web|last=Singer|first=P.W.|title=Military Robots and the Laws of War|url=http://www.thenewatlantis.com/publications/military-robots-and-the-laws-of-war|publisher=The New Atlantis|date=Winter 2009}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Ofek|first=Hillel|title=The Tortured Logic of Obama's Drone War|url=http://www.thenewatlantis.com/publications/the-tortured-logic-of-obamas-drone-war|work=The New Atlantis|date=Spring 2010}}</ref> [[chemical weapons]],<ref>{{cite web|last=Tucker|first=Jonathan B.|title=The Future of Chemical Weapons|url=http://www.thenewatlantis.com/publications/the-future-of-chemical-weapons|publisher=The New Atlantis|date=Fall 2009}}</ref> and [[cyberwarfare]].<ref>{{cite web|last=Ford|first=Christopher A.|title=The Trouble With Cyber Arms Control|url=http://www.thenewatlantis.com/publications/the-trouble-with-cyber-arms-control|date=Fall 2010}}</ref> Articles often explore policy questions on these and other issues, sometimes advocating particular policy outcomes, especially on health care,<ref>{{cite web|title=Health care|url=http://www.thenewatlantis.com/publications/topic/health-care|accessdate=December 6, 2012}}</ref> environmental management,<ref>{{cite web|title=Environmentalism|url=http://www.thenewatlantis.com/publications/topic/environmentalism|accessdate=December 6, 2012}}</ref> and energy.<ref>{{cite web|title=Energy|url=http://www.thenewatlantis.com/publications/topic/energy|accessdate=December 6, 2012}}</ref>
The journal has published widely on [[bioethics]], including issues such as [[stem cell research]],<ref>{{cite web|title=Stem cell research|url=http://www.thenewatlantis.com/publications/topic/stem-cell-research|accessdate=December 6, 2012}}</ref> [[assisted reproduction]],<ref>{{cite web|title=Assisted reproductive technologies|url=http://www.thenewatlantis.com/publications/topic/assisted-reproductive-technologies|accessdate=December 6, 2012}}</ref> [[cloning]],<ref>{{cite web|title=Cloning|url=http://www.thenewatlantis.com/publications/topic/cloning|accessdate=December 6, 2012}}</ref> [[assisted suicide]],<ref>{{cite web|title=End of life|url=http://www.thenewatlantis.com/publications/topic/end-of-life|accessdate=December 6, 2012}}</ref> [[organ donation|organ and tissue donation]],<ref>{{cite web|title=Organ transplantation|url=http://www.thenewatlantis.com/publications/topic/organ-transplantation|accessdate=December 6, 2012}}</ref> the purported [[Vaccine controversies|link between vaccines and autism]],<ref>{{cite web|last=Nicol|first=Caitrin|title=Shot in the Dark|url=http://www.thenewatlantis.com/publications/shot-in-the-dark|work=The New Atlantis|date=Fall 2007}}</ref> and [[informed consent]].<ref>{{cite web|last=Schulman|first=Ari N.|title=What is the Body Worth?|url=http://www.thenewatlantis.com/publications/what-is-the-body-worth|publisher=The New Atlantis|date=Spring 2012}}</ref> Articles on these issues often highlight the potential for dangerous or degrading developments, including concerns over [[human dignity]],<ref>{{cite web|title=Human dignity|url=http://www.thenewatlantis.com/publications/topic/human-dignity|accessdate=December 6, 2012}}</ref> with many articles examining [[human enhancement]],<ref name="thenewatlantis">{{cite web|title=Enhancement|url=http://www.thenewatlantis.com/publications/topic/enhancement|accessdate=December 6, 2012}}</ref> and [[life extension]],<ref>{{cite web|title=Agelessness|url=http://www.thenewatlantis.com/publications/topic/agelessness|accessdate=December 6, 2012}}</ref> and historical precedents for abuse in [[eugenics]]<ref>{{cite web|title=Historical eugenics|url=http://www.thenewatlantis.com/publications/topic/eugenics-historical|accessdate=December 6, 2012}}</ref> and [[population control]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Contemporary eugenics|url=http://www.thenewatlantis.com/publications/topic/eugenics-contemporary|accessdate=December 6, 2012}}</ref>
The journal also features broader philosophical reflections on science and technology, and tends to be skeptical of what its authors consider to be speculative overreach common in popular discussions. Examples include articles that have defended the existence of [[free will]] in light of developments in [[neuroscience]],<ref>{{cite web|last=Tallis|first=Raymond|title=How Can I Possibly Be Free?|url=http://www.thenewatlantis.com/publications/how-can-i-possibly-be-free|publisher=The New Atlantis|date=Summer 2010}}</ref> questioned the wisdom of using [[neuroimaging|brain scans]] in courtrooms,<ref>{{cite web|last=Snead|first=Carter|title=Neuroimaging and Capital Punishment|url=http://www.thenewatlantis.com/publications/neuroimaging-and-capital-punishment|publisher=The New Atlantis|date=Winter 2008}}</ref> and described how growing knowledge of [[epigenetics]] has undermined common claims about [[genetic determinism]].<ref>{{cite web|last=Talbott |first=Stephen L. |title=Getting Over the Code Delusion |url=http://www.thenewatlantis.com/publications/getting-over-the-code-delusion |publisher=The New Atlantis |date=Summer 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121004025933/http://www.thenewatlantis.com/publications/getting-over-the-code-delusion |archivedate=October 4, 2012}}</ref> While the journal has sometimes aired [[libertarianism|libertarian]] views about [[human enhancement]] and [[transhumanism]],<ref>{{cite web|last=Bailey|first=Ronald|title=The Case for Enhancing People|url=http://www.thenewatlantis.com/publications/the-case-for-enhancing-people|publisher=The New Atlantis|date=Summer 2011}}</ref> its contributors generally tend to question whether technologies like [[artificial intelligence]],<ref>{{cite web|title=Artificial intelligence|url=http://www.thenewatlantis.com/publications/topic/artificial-intelligence|accessdate=December 6, 2012}}</ref> [[Friendly ai|"friendly" artificial intelligence]],<ref>{{cite web|title=The Problem with 'Friendly' Artificial Intelligence|url=http://www.thenewatlantis.com/publications/the-problem-with-friendly-artificial-intelligence|publisher=The New Atlantis|author1=Keiper, Adam |author2=Schulman, Ari N. |lastauthoramp=yes |date=Summer 2011}}</ref> and [[genetic enhancement]]<ref name="thenewatlantis" /><ref>{{cite web|title=Genetic engineering|url=http://www.thenewatlantis.com/publications/topic/genetic-engineering|accessdate=December 6, 2012}}</ref> are possible or desirable. The journal also publishes the [http://futurisms.thenewatlantis.com/ Futurisms blog], dedicated to criticizing transhumanism.
The journal has also published widely on the interpersonal effects of the Internet and digital technology. It has featured articles on subjects like [[Facebook]],<ref>{{cite web|last=Boyd|first=Brian|title=The Dotcomrade|url=http://www.thenewatlantis.com/publications/the-dotcomrade|publisher=The New Atlantis|date=Fall 2006}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Rosen|first=Christine|title=Virtual Friendship and the New Narcissism|url=http://www.thenewatlantis.com/publications/virtual-friendship-and-the-new-narcissism|publisher=The New Atlantis|date=Summer 2007}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Scruton|first=Roger|title=Hiding Behind the Screen|url=http://www.thenewatlantis.com/publications/hiding-behind-the-screen|publisher=The New Atlantis|date=Summer 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Waisman|first=Sebastian|title=We Are the Change We've Been Waiting For|url=http://www.thenewatlantis.com/publications/we-are-the-change-weve-been-waiting-for|publisher=The New Atlantis|date=Summer 2008}}</ref> [[cell phones]],<ref>{{cite web|last=Rosen|first=Christine|title=Our Cell Phones, Ourselves|url=http://www.thenewatlantis.com/publications/our-cell-phones-ourselves|publisher=The New Atlantis|date=Summer 2004}}</ref> [[multitasking]],<ref>{{cite web|last=Rosen|first=Christine|title=The Myth of Multitasking|url=http://www.thenewatlantis.com/publications/the-myth-of-multitasking|publisher=The New Atlantis|date=Spring 2008}}</ref> [[E-book reader|e-readers]],<ref>{{cite web|last=Rosen|first=Christine|title=People of the Screen|url=http://www.thenewatlantis.com/publications/people-of-the-screen|publisher=The New Atlantis|date=Fall 2008}}</ref> [[GPS]] and navigation,<ref>{{cite web|last=Schulman|first=Ari N.|title=GPS and the End of the Road|url=http://www.thenewatlantis.com/publications/gps-and-the-end-of-the-road|publisher=The New Atlantis|date=Spring 2011}}</ref> and [[virtual reality]].<ref>{{cite web|last=Koganzon|first=Rita|title=The World Made New|url=http://www.thenewatlantis.com/publications/the-world-made-new|publisher=The New Atlantis|date=Summer 2008}}</ref> A 2006 article by [[Matthew Crawford|Matthew B. Crawford]] advocating the intellectual and economic virtues of the [[Trade (occupation)|manual trades]]<ref>{{cite web|last=Crawford|first=Matthew B.|title=Shop Class as Soulcraft|url=http://www.thenewatlantis.com/publications/shop-class-as-soulcraft|publisher=The New Atlantis|date=Summer 2006}}</ref> was noted as a best-of-the-year essay by ''New York Times'' columnist [[David Brooks (journalist)|David Brooks]],<ref>{{cite news|last=Brooks|first=David|title=The Sidney Awards|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2006/12/14/opinion/14brooks.html|newspaper=The New York Times|date=December 14, 2006}}</ref> and was subsequently expanded into the bestselling<ref>{{Cite news|title=Best Sellers|url=https://www.nytimes.com/best-sellers-books/2009-07-19/hardcover-nonfiction/list.html|newspaper=The New York Times|accessdate=7 December 2012|date=July 19, 2009}}</ref> book ''Shop Class as Soulcraft''.<ref>{{cite book|last=Crawford|first=Matthew B.|title=Shop Class as Soulcraft|year=2009|publisher=Penguin|isbn=978-0143117469}}</ref> The journal also frequently publishes essays on philosophical and literary questions relating to science and technology.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thenewatlantis.com/publications/hawthorne-series-science-progress-and-human-nature |title=Hawthorne: Science, Progress, and Human Nature|publisher=The New Atlantis|accessdate=2012-12-06}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thenewatlantis.com/publications/the-physicists-at-fifty |title=''The Physicists'' at Fifty |first=Samuel|last=Matlack |publisher=The New Atlantis |date=Summer 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thenewatlantis.com/publications/the-folly-of-scientism |title=The Folly of Scientism |first=Austin L.|last=Hughes |publisher=The New Atlantis |date=Fall 2012}}</ref>
==Book Series== ''The New Atlantis'' also publishes a book series, New Atlantis Books, an imprint of [[Encounter Books]]. To date, six books have been released: * ''In the Shadow of Progress: Being Human in the Age of Technology'' {{ISBN|9781594032080}} (2008), by Eric Cohen<ref>{{cite book|last=Cohen|first=Eric|title=In the Shadow of Progress: Being Human in the Age of Technology|year=2008|publisher=Encounter Books|location=New York|isbn=9781594032080|ref=harv}}</ref> * ''Imagining the Future: Science and American Democracy'' {{ISBN|9781594032097}} (2008), by [[Yuval Levin]]<ref>{{cite book|last=Levin|first=Yuval|title=Imagining the Future: Science and American Democracy |year=2008|publisher=Encounter Books|location=New York|isbn=9781594032097|ref=harv}}</ref> * ''Neither Beast nor God: The Dignity of the Human Person'' {{ISBN|9781594032578}} (2009), by Gilbert Meilaender<ref>{{cite book|last=Meilaender |first=Gilbert|title=Neither Beast nor God: The Dignity of the Human Person |year=2009|publisher=Encounter Books|location=New York|isbn=9781594032578|ref=harv}}</ref> * ''Merchants of Despair: Radical Environmentalists, Criminal Pseudo-Scientists, and the Fatal Cult of Antihumanism'' {{ISBN|9781594034763}} (2012), by [[Robert Zubrin]]<ref>{{cite book|last=Zubrin |first=Robert|title= Merchants of Despair: Radical Environmentalists, Criminal Pseudo-Scientists, and the Fatal Cult of Antihumanism|year=2012|publisher=Encounter Books|location=New York|isbn=9781594034763|ref=harv}}</ref> * ''Why Place Matters: Geography, Identity, and Civic Life in Modern America'' {{ISBN|9781594037160}} (2014), edited by [[Wilfred M. McClay]] and Ted. V. McAllister<ref>{{cite book|editor1-last=McClay |editor1-first=Wilfred M. |editor1-link=Wilfred M. McClay |editor2-last=McAllister |editor2-first=Ted V. |title= Why Place Matters: Geography, Identity, and Civic Life in Modern America|year=2014|publisher=Encounter Books|location=New York|isbn=9781594037160|ref=harv}}</ref> * ''Eclipse of Man: Human Extinction and the Meaning of Progress'' {{ISBN|9781594037368}} (2014), by [[Charles T. Rubin]]<ref>{{Cite book|title = Eclipse of Man: Human Extinction and the Meaning of Progress|last = Rubin|first = Charles T.|publisher = Encounter Books|year = 2014|isbn = 9781594037368|location = New York|pages = }}</ref>
==Contributors== {{Unreferenced section|date=August 2016}} Among the more notable contributors to the journal are physicians and bioethicists such as [[The President's Council on Bioethics|President’s Council on Bioethics]] chairman [[Leon Kass]] and neuroscientist [[William B. Hurlbut]]; prominent scientists such as [[Raymond Tallis]], [[Sara Seager]], and [[Marcelo Gleiser]]; political scientists, legal and ethical scholars, and policy analysts such as [[Yuval Levin]], [[Robert P. George]], [[Peter Augustine Lawler]], [[Diana Schaub]], [[Charles T. Rubin]], [[Jeffrey Rosen]], [[Larry Arnhart]], and [[Jonathan B. Tucker]]; think-tank scholars such as [[Nicholas Eberstadt]], [[Roger Bate]], [[Henry Sokolski]], and [[Robert D. Atkinson]]; space experts and entrepreneurs such as [[Mars Society]] founder [[Robert Zubrin]], [[James C. Bennett]], and [[Jeff Foust]]; and philosophers, historians, authors, and journalists such as [[Roger Scruton]], [[Gertrude Himmelfarb]], [[Matthew Crawford|Matthew B. Crawford]], [[Harvey Mansfield]], [[Wilfred M. McClay]], [[Ross Douthat]], [[Victor Davis Hanson]], [[Alan Jacobs (academic)|Alan Jacobs]], [[Varadaraja V. Raman]], [[Stephen Snobelen|Stephen D. Snobelen]], [[Andrew Janiak]], [[William R. Newman]], and [[Ronald Bailey]].
==Reception== Writing for the National Review in a 2003 column, the conservative author Stanley Kurtz described ''The New Atlantis'' as influential on thinking about science and technology.<ref>{{cite news|last=Kurtz |first=Stanley |title=Brave New World of Dna? |url=http://www.nationalreview.com/corner/64904/brave-new-world-dna/stanley-kurtz |newspaper=The Corner |date=May 29, 2003 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140303042653/http://www.nationalreview.com/corner/64904/brave-new-world-dna/stanley-kurtz |archivedate=March 3, 2014}} </ref><ref>{{cite journal|last=Moreno|first=Jonathan D.|title=Biotechnology and the New Right: Neoconservatism's Red Menace|journal=American Journal of Bioethics|date=October 2007|volume=7|issue=10|url=http://www.bioethics.net/articles/biotechnology-and-the-new-right-neoconservatisms-red-menace/}}</ref>
[[Richard John Neuhaus]], late editor of the conservative journal ''[[First Things]]'', wrote that ''The New Atlantis'' is "as good a publication as there is for the intelligent exploration of questions in bioethics and projections—promising, ominous, and fantastical—about the human future,"<ref>{{cite news|last=Neuhaus|first=Richard John|title=A number of readers have..|url=http://www.firstthings.com/onthesquare/2005/10/a-number-of-readers-have|newspaper=On the Square|date=October 6, 2005}}</ref> and a writer in ''[[The American Conservative]]'' described the journal as a source "of fresh ideas on the Right."<ref>{{cite news|last=Bramwell|first=Austin|title=Defining Conservatism Down|url=http://www.theamericanconservative.com/articles/defining-conservatism-down/|newspaper=The American Conservative|date=August 29, 2005}}</ref> ''[[National Review]]'' columnist [[Jonah Goldberg]] described ''The New Atlantis'' as "a new and interesting magazine" that "seems to be trying to carve out the space for the government to stop the more offensive aspects of biotechnology."<ref>{{cite news|last=Goldberg|first=Jonah|title=Ones & Zeroes Have Consequences|url=http://www.nationalreview.com/articles/207235/ones-zeroes-have-consequences/jonah-goldberg#|newspaper=National Review|date=June 16, 2003}}</ref>
By contrast, the liberal bioethicist [[Jonathan D. Moreno]] has said that the journal offers "a very dark vision" about science and technology, but that it "makes an important point about the need to worry about the ends as well as means in science"<ref>{{cite journal|title=Point Counterpoint|journal=Science|date=2 November 2007|volume=318|issue=5851|pages=725|doi=10.1126/science.318.5851.725d}}</ref> and that its "writers were young, smart, and had a good understanding of the political process and the making of public policy."<ref name="MIT">{{cite book|last=Berger|first=Sam|title=Progress in Bioethics: Science, Policy, and Politics|year=2010|publisher=M.I.T. Press|location=Cambridge, Mass.|isbn=978-0262517423|author2=Jonathan D. Moreno |editor=Sam Berger and Jonathan D. Moreno|page=xviii|chapter=Introduction}}</ref> Bioethicist [[Ruth Macklin]] criticized ''The New Atlantis'' as representative of a conservative movement in bioethics that is "mean-spirited, mystical, and emotional" and that "claims insight into ultimate truth yet disavows reason."<ref name="Hastings">{{cite journal|last=Macklin|first=Ruth|title=The New Conservatives in Bioethics: Who Are They and What Do They Seek?|journal=The Hastings Center Report|date=January–February 2006|volume=36|issue=1|pages=34–43|url=http://www.thehastingscenter.org/Publications/HCR/Detail.aspx?id=2890|doi=10.1353/hcr.2006.0013|pmid=16544839}}</ref>
The journal has particularly gained a reputation among the [[transhumanist]] movement for its criticism of human enhancement. [[James Hughes (sociologist)|James Hughes]], a [[Techno-progressivism|techno-progressivist]] and at times director of organizations such as the [[World Transhumanist Association]] and the [[Institute for Ethics and Emerging Technologies]], notes that the journal "has published influential attacks on artificial intelligence, nanotechnology, biotechnology, reproductive technology, and life extension." [[Natasha Vita-More]] has described it as a "journal known as a ring of bioconservatives bent on opposing the cyberculture," while the [[Extropy Institute]] has called it "a high-powered rallying point for the neo-Luddites."<ref>{{cite web|title=About the Vital Progress Summit|url=http://www.extropy.org/summitabout.htm|publisher=Extropy Institute|accessdate=December 6, 2012}}</ref>

[[File:Tibetan prayer wheel.jpg|thumb|Tibetan hand prayer wheel]] '''Prayer Wheels''' (Tibetan: ''mani ´khor lo'') are widely used in Tibet and areas where [[Tibetan culture]] is predominant.
==Hand prayer wheel== The most common form of these objects are hand prayer wheels (Tibetan ''ma ni lag ´khor'' ) which consist of a metal cylinder and a handle which also serves as axis around which the cylinder can revolve, being set in motion by a small weight which is attached to it by a string or chain. The cylinder contains a paper roll on which Buddhist texts are printed. When the prayer wheel is spun in prayer, the mantras inside become potent with the person's intent.
==Other forms of prayer wheels== Apart from hand prayer wheels there exist large size fixed prayer wheels which are often aligned around Buddhist shrines and are set in motion by pilgrims who circum-ambulate the building in a clockwise direction. Prayer wheels larger than human size are to be seen in separate rooms in [[Tibetan Buddhism|Tibetan Buddhist]] temples and can also be set in motion by pilgrims. With the help of a small bell the number of revolutions can be counted. The cylinders of fixed prayer wheels are often inscribed with the formula “[[Om mani padme hum]]” (meaning “jewel in the lotus”) in ornamental Lantsa ([[Ranjana script|Ranjana]]) letters. Prayer wheels (perhaps more appropriately called “prayer mills”) which are set in motion by wind or water power are also known. They are used for prayer of Tibetan festival.
==Origin of prayer wheels== Some experts believe that the prayer wheels evolved from revolving octagonal Chinese bookcases which were first recorded in the 9th century CE. This assumption is supported by the existence of octagonal prayer wheels in [[Mongolia]].
==See also== *[[Prayer wheel]]
==References==
* Goodrich, L. Carrington: “The Revolving Book-Case in China”. Harvard Journal of Asiatic Studies, vol. 7, Cambridge, Mass., 1942-43, p. 130-161. *Hunter, Alwin: "Tibetan Prayer Wheels". ''Arts of Asia'', vol. 15, no. 1 (January/February 1985), p. 74-81. *Martin, Dan: “On the Origin and Significance of the Prayer Wheel According to two Nineteenth-Century Tibetan Literary Sources”. ''Journal of the Tibet Society'', vol. 7, Indiana University, 1987 *Simpson, William: ''The Buddhist Praying Wheel'', London, 1896

{{coord|36|40|33.67|N|117|3|38.05|E|region:CN_type:landmark|display=title}}
[[Image:Tomb of min ziqian jinan hall 2009 07.jpg|thumb|right|200px|Hall on the site of the tomb, with two ''[[bixi (tortoise)|bixi]]'' turtles (deprived of their stelae)]]
The '''Tomb of Min Ziqian''' ({{zh|c={{linktext|闵|子|骞|墓}}|p=Mǐn Zǐqiān Mù}}) is a memorial to [[Min Sun]] ([[courtesy name]] Ziqian, 536 BCE-?<ref name=analects>[https://books.google.com/books?id=wqym0cOd33MC&pg=PA201 The Analects of Confucius By Confucius, Chichung Huang]</ref>), a disciple of [[Confucius]] and the fourth of the [[The Twenty-four Filial Exemplars|24 Confucian paragons of filial piety]].<ref name=24paragons>[http://www.ruf.rice.edu/~asia/24ParagonsFilialPiety.html The Twenty-Four Paragons of Filial Piety]</ref> The memorial is located in [[Jinan]], the capital of [[Shandong]] Province, China.
While the memorial is designed as a classical Confucian tomb with an ancestral temple, a [[spirit way]], and a burial mound, the actual burial place of Min Sun is not known.<ref name=xinhua>[http://big5.xinhuanet.com/gate/big5/www.sd.xinhua.org/sdsq/2006-03/30/content_6610582.htm Min Ziqian: Shandong's Great Filial Son {{zh icon}}]</ref> Only some of Min Sun's clothes may have been buried at the Jinan site.<ref name=xinhua /> Other places in [[Jiangsu]], [[Henan]], and [[Anhui]] also have tombs erected to commemorate Min Sun.<ref name=xinhua />
[[Image:Tomb of min ziqian jinan spirit way 2009 07.jpg|thumb|right|200px|[[Spirit Way]] leading to the burial mound]]
The first records of the construction of an ancestral hall dedicated to Min Ziqian on the site in Jinan date to the year 1074 in the period of the [[Northern Song Dynasty]].<ref name=xinhua /> Renovations were undertaken during the [[Yuan Dynasty|Yuan]], [[Ming Dynasty|Ming]] and [[Qing Dynasty|Qing]] Dynasties.<ref name=sina>[http://news.sina.com.cn/culture/2000-3-27/76042.html Jinan's Min Ziqian Tomb in Disrepair for Many Years {{zh icon}}]</ref><ref name=jnfdc.gov>[http://www.jnfdc.gov.cn/Housebiz/GeneralSituation/GeneralSituation_qcms_qcls_407.htm Min Ziqian Tomb {{zh icon}}]{{Dead link|date=July 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=no }}</ref> Prior to the [[Cultural Revolution]], the area covered by the memorial spanned about 300 meters in the north–south direction and 200 meters along the east–west axis.<ref name=sina /> The burial mount had a diameter of 78 meters and a height of 10 meters. The site also featured more than 30 old trees and more than 10 historical stone sculptures. The memorial sustained significant damage during the Cultural Revolution,<ref name=sina /><ref name=jnfdc.gov /> when the ancestral hall was torn down, masonry was destroyed, and trees were cut down.<ref name=sina /> In September 1979, the memorial was identified as the first of Jinan's key historical sites deserving protection. At present, the site covers an area of only 60 (north–south) by 30 meters (east–west).<ref name=jnfdc.gov /> A project to restore the tomb began in 1999, but ran out of funds.<ref name=jnwh.gov>[http://www.jnwh.gov.cn/read.php%3FPid%3D495 Min Ziqian's tomb about to open after five-year renovation {{zh icon}}]</ref>
==Location== The tomb is located to the east of Min Ziqian Road, adjacent to the [[Jinan Baihua Park|Baihua Park]], formerly known as "[[Catkin]]s Park" in reference to the story about Min Ziqian's extraordinary [[filial piety]].
==See also== *[[List of sites in Jinan]]
==References== {{commons category|Tomb of Min Ziqian}} {{reflist}}

{{Use dmy dates|date=December 2014}} [[File:Vydūnas 1930.jpg|thumb|Vydūnas in 1930]] [[Image:Wilhelm_Storost_(Vilius_Storostas-Vydūnas)_on_200_LTL_banknote.png|thumb|Vydunas as featured on 200 [[Lithuanian litas|litas]] banknote (1997 release)]] [[Image:Vydūnas plays a harp.jpeg|thumb|Vydūnas playing harp at home]] [[Image:Vydūnas delivers a speech.jpeg|thumb|Vydūnas holding a funeral speech in 1931 m.]]
'''Wilhelm Storost''', artistic name '''Vilius Storostas-Vydūnas''' (22 March 1868 – 20 February 1953), mostly known as '''Vydūnas''', was a [[Prussian-Lithuanian]]<ref>"Lietuvininkas Vydūnas" {{cite web |url=http://www.mazoji-lietuva.lt/article.php?article=23 |title=Vydūnas – Mažosios Lietuvos istorikas |year=1993 |author=Dr. Algirdas Matulevičius |accessdate=15 October 2007 |language=lt |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070710182730/http://www.mazoji-lietuva.lt/article.php?article=23 |archive-date=10 July 2007 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }}</ref> teacher, poet, humanist, philosopher and Lithuanian<ref name=Bagonavicius>{{cite book|editor=Jūrate Baranova|title=Lithuanian philosophy: persons and ideas Lithuanian philosophical studies, ii|origyear=2001|url=http://www.crvp.org/book/Series04/IVA-17/contents.htm|accessdate=7 September 2007|series=Cultural heritage and contemporary change series iva, Eastern and Central Europe, volume 17|publisher=Council for Research in Values and philosophy|location=Washington, D.C.|isbn=1-56518-137-9|chapter=Chapter VII Vydunas: the essential features of his philosophy by Vaclovas Bagdonavičius|chapterurl=http://www.crvp.org/book/Series04/IVA-17/chapter_vii.htm|year=2000|display-editors=etal|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070928011758/http://www.crvp.org/book/Series04/IVA-17/contents.htm|archivedate=28 September 2007|df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref>{{cite book | last = Welters | first = Linda | authorlink = | title = Folk Dress in Europe and Anatolia: Beliefs About Protection and Fertility | publisher = Berg Publishers | year = 1999 | location = | quote = Lithuanian philosopher Vydunas|url = | doi = | id = | isbn = 1-85973-287-9| page = 214 }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | first=Daiva | last=Prof. Kšanienė | title=Vydūnas | date=9 October 2003 | publisher= | url=http://www.mazoji-lietuva.lt/article.php?article=158 | journal=Voruta | pages= | accessdate=16 October 2007 | language=Lithuanian | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070707190625/http://www.mazoji-lietuva.lt/article.php?article=158 | archive-date=7 July 2007 | dead-url=yes | df=dmy-all }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|title=A conversation with Tomas Venclova|journal=Lituanus|year=1979|first=Kazys|last=Bradūnas|authorlink=Kazys Bradūnas|volume=25|issue=3|pages=|id= |url=http://www.lituanus.org/1979/79_3_05.htm|accessdate=16 October 2007 }}</ref> writer and philosopher, a leader of the Prussian Lithuanian national movement in [[Lithuania Minor]], and one of leaders of the [[Theosophy (Blavatskian)|theosophical movement]] in [[East Prussia]].
==Biography== The Storost family was for centuries living in [[East-Prussia]] and Wilhelm was born in the village [[Šilutė District Municipality|Jonaten]] ({{lang-lt|Jonaičiai}}), near [[Šilutė|Heydekrug]], in the [[Kingdom of Prussia]]. '''Wilhelm Storost''' was the name on his German passport, while '''Vilimas''' or '''Vilius Storostas'''<!--Storostas su s jis pats vadinosi kaip nustatyta --> was the literature Lithuanian form used by himself, his family, and other Lithuanians. "Vydūnas" was added to his surname as a pseudonym when he was about 40 years old. Storost was married to Klara Füllhase.
Storost was educated as teacher at the Präparandenanstalt in [[Pillkallen]] (1883–85) and at teacher seminar in [[Ragnit]] (1885–88). From 1888 to 1892 he was a teacher in Kinten (lit. Kintai), when he went to teach at a boys school in [[Tilsit]] until 1912 and taught German, French, English, Lithuanian and sports. In 1912 he left his teaching position in order to take up philosophical studies, which he took at the universities of [[University of Greifswald|Greifswald]], [[University of Halle-Wittenberg|Halle]], [[University of Leipzig|Leipzig]] and [[Humboldt University of Berlin|Berlin]]. 1918/19 he taught Lithuanian at the Seminar for Oriental Languages in Berlin under the director [[Eduard Sachau]]. Back in Tilsit he dedicated himself to reestablishment of Lithuanian Culture, especially folks songs and rural traditions. He directed a choir and wrote songs as well as theater plays. From 1933 on he worked in Memel at the music school.
1932 he wrote a book ''Sieben Hundert Jahren Deutsch-Litauischer Beziehung'' (Seven Hundred Years of German-Lithuanian relations). His idea of understanding between folks groups did not please the Nazis and in 1933 the book was outlawed. 1938 he was shortly incarcerated, but because of protests released after two months.
Together with nearly all of the people of East Prussia he was expelled during Communist take-over and lived in a refugee camp for some time. He died in [[Detmold]], [[West Germany]]. His grand nephews, Jürgen Storost, recently explained, that Wilhelm Storost's answered his friend [[Viktor Falkenhahn]], that "his use of the pen name Vydunas was his chosen [[anthroposophic]] mission; that he did not want to be a "pavydūnas", but a "vydūnas" (one who wishes everyone everything good).
Vydūnas was active in the old Lithuanian pagan religion (see [[Romuva (religion)|Romuva]]). However, he never declared the revival of the pagan religion as either his personal goal or a goal of Lithuanians, remaining a national leader but not a religious one. His moral influence transcended the confines of being a typical political leader or a writer at his time. He was compared by later biographers with national leaders in [[India]] of his time, such as [[Rabindranath Tagore]] or [[Mahatma Gandhi]]. [[Pantheism|Pantheistic]] [[universalism]], not predefined with participating in any obligatory religious practice, was one of the leading ideas of his philosophy, and gained him later fame as a pioneer of both pagan revival and theosophy in [[Lithuania]].
Vydūnas was an ethical vegetarian, and wrote several essays about his ethical choices.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://animalrights.lt/pasisakymai-vydunas | title = Žymių žmonių pasisakymai apie gyvūnų išnaudojimą | publisher= Animal Rights Lithuania | accessdate=7 December 2008}} ''(in Lithuanian)''</ref>
Vydūnas was considered a candidate for the Nobel Prize by Lithuanian writers association.<ref name=Bagonavicius/><ref>{{cite journal|title=Laisvės ir literatūros hipostazės|journal=Mokslo Lietuva|year=2000|first=Arvydas|last=Genys|volume=|issue=4|url=http://ic.lms.lt/ml/206/laisves.htm|accessdate=7 September 2007|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070927225452/http://ic.lms.lt/ml/206/laisves.htm|archivedate=27 September 2007|df=dmy-all}}</ref>

[[wikt:武|武]][[wikt:楨|楨]] | image = | imagesize = | alt = | caption = | birth_date = 1759 | birth_place = [[Lương Tài]], [[Đại Việt]] | death_date = 1828 | death_place = [[Lương Tài]], Đại Việt | occupation = Royal official | language = [[Vietnamese language|Vietnamese]], [[Hán tự]] | period = [[Revival Lê dynasty]], [[Nguyễn dynasty]] | genre = [[Judiciary]] | subject = | movement = | notableworks = ''[[Nguyễn triều hình luật]]'', ''[[Sứ Yên thi tập]]'', ''[[Cung oán thi tập]]'' | influences = | influenced = }} '''Vũ Trinh''' ({{lang-vi-hantu|武楨}}; 1759–1828) (pseudonames 萊山 and 蘭池漁者) was a well-known [[Confucianism|Confucianist]] in [[Tonkin]] and high-ranking [[Mandarin (bureaucrat)|mandarin]] in both Le Trinh dynasty and Nguyen dynasty. Vũ Trinh was born in a noble family with many proficient Confucian scholars in Ngọc Quan hamlet, Lương Tài district, [[Bắc Ninh]]. His grandfather was [[Vũ Miên]]: Headmaster of [[Guozijian|Quốc Tử Giám]] and [[Grand chancellor (China)|Chancellor]]. He got title Giải nguyên (解元) ([[:vi:Giải nguyên|First laureate]]) in the interprovincial Confucian examination that was held every three years with small quantity of selected candidates when he was only 17, then became a mandarin. In his career path, at very young age (29 years old), he was promoted to be Vice [[Grand chancellor (China)|Chancellor]] (參知政事). He declined the invitation of [[Ngô Thì Nhậm]], a great mandarin of Tay Son for a mandarin position. For this, he was mentioned in a poem written by Nguyễn Đề, stored in [[Qing dynasty]]'s Literature records: '''次東山偶憶蘭溪漁者''' 東魯行車雨雪飛， 偶懷閒客釣魚磯。 二倫情誼心相合， 十載窮通命每違。 不審役形當世事， 何如拭目看時機。 首陽今日無人問， 也任夷齊採盡薇。 Along with being a mandarin, he was also a writer. His legacies were mostly written in Chinese. [[File:HoangVietLoatLe first page.jpg|center|thumb|382x382px|First page of 皇越律例, also known as "Gia Long Code", by [[Nguyễn Văn Thành|Nguyen Van Thanh]], Vu Trinh, Tran Huu]] == Notable works== 使燕詩集

{{confused|wicked (disambiguation)}} {{wiktionary|wickedness|wicked}} '''Wickedness''' is generally considered a synonym for [[evil]] or [[sin]]fulness. Among theologians and philosophers, it has the [[Technical terminology|more specific meaning]] of evil committed [[Consciousness#In philosophy|consciously]] and of [[free will]].<ref>{{cite web| first= Ron |last= Rosenbaum |authorlink= Ron Rosenbaum | url= http://www.slate.com/articles/health_and_science/the_spectator/2011/09/does_evil_exist_neuroscientists_say_no_.single.html | title= The End of Evil? | date= September 30, 2011 | publisher= [[Slate (magazine)|Slate]] | accessdate= 2011-10-10}}</ref> It can also be considered the quality or state of being wicked.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/wickedness|title=Definition of WICKEDNESS|website=www.merriam-webster.com|access-date=2016-12-05}}</ref>
The term wickedness dates back to the 1300s and is derived from the words ''wicked'' and ''-ness''. Wicked is an extended form of the term wick meaning bad and is also associated with the Old English term ''wicca'' meaning wizard. There isn’t a corresponding verb to the term, but the term wretched is also associated with the term. The term -ness is a word forming element denoting action, quality or state and is typically added to an adjective or past participle to make it an abstract noun. It is an Old English term and also comes from the Proto-Germanic term ''in-assu'' and many other cognates.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.etymonline.com/index.php?allowed_in_frame=0&search=wickedness|title=Online Etymology Dictionary|website=www.etymonline.com|access-date=2016-12-05}}</ref>
As characterized by [[Martin Buber]] in his 1952 work ''Bilder von Gut und Böse'' (translated as ''Good and Evil: Two Interpretations''),<!-- this is a quote of the characterization as opposed to a translation --> "The first stage of evil is '[[sin]],' occasional [[wikt:directionlessness|directionlessness]]. Endless possibility can be overwhelming, leading man to grasp at anything, distracting and busying himself, in order to not have to make a real, committed choice. The second stage of evil is 'wickedness,' when caprice is embraced as a deformed substitute for [[will (philosophy)|genuine will]] and becomes characteristic."<ref>{{cite web| first= Sarah |last= Scott| work= [[Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy]] | url= http://www.iep.utm.edu/buber/#SH2e | title= Martin Buber (1878—1965) | date= July 9, 2010 | publisher= [[University of Tennessee at Martin]] | issn= 2161-0002 <!-- sic -->| accessdate= 2011-10-10}}</ref> Wickedness [[connotation|connotes]] [[wikt:blameworthiness|blameworthiness]].<ref>{{cite web| first= Garrath |last= Williams | work= [[Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy]] | url= http://www.iep.utm.edu/responsi/#H3 | title= Responsibility | date= March 9, 2009 | publisher= [[University of Tennessee at Martin]] | issn= 2161-0002 <!-- sic -->| accessdate= 2011-10-10}}</ref>
==Wickedness and Power== Throughout history power is typically seen to be a very dangerous and destructive element in people’s lives. It’s a canker to society or is wicked if you will. Some theorists believe that power itself is actually in fact morally neutral. It is the results of power that determine whether or not power is seen as good. The people in power are then also seen as not wicked in their nature, but rather the urgency for power and within the nature of it is what makes power seen as a wicked idea. Theorists believe that if men were the wicked ones in the equation then the solution to the issues at stake would be ethical improvement. In the end, it isn’t power or man that are wicked, but the results of power that cause it to be wicked.<ref>French, A. (1980). Thucydides and the Power Syndrome. Greece & Rome, 27(1), 22-30. Retrieved from <nowiki>http://mccclib.mccc.edu:2112/stable/642773</nowiki></ref>
==What Causes Someone to be Wicked== There are two different types of wickedness that some people will argue. There is natural wickedness. This is the type of wickedness that is unpreventable such as earthquakes, tornadoes and other types of natural disasters. The second type of wickedness is moral wickedness. This type of wickedness is types of evil that are acted out by humans and can arguably be preventable. What causes the separation between the two is the response to both types of wickedness. During a natural disaster people tend to be sympathetic to the victims of the destruction. It’s this sympathy to the victims that classifies a natural disaster as a form of wickedness. In contrast, to moral wickedness where people will be sympathetic to the victim of the person who committed the wicked behavior. This distinguishes the person who committed the act as a wicked being. It is based on the modern consciousness of society that determines whether the act is considered wicked.<ref>Billias, Nancy (2010) Promoting and Producing Evil. <nowiki>http://mccclib.mccc.edu:2094/lib/mccc/detail.action?docID=10447250&p00=%22promoting+and+producing+evil%22</nowiki></ref>
==Heavy Metal and Wickedness== Heavy Metal is a genre of music with lyrics that are dark and people consider to be satanic. It was introduced on Friday the 13th in February 1970 when Black Sabbath released Black Sabbath. Around this time period the Vietnam War was going on, the deaths of Martin Luther King Jr. and John F. Kennedy occurred, the death of Flower Power and the second Cold War was coming into play. These events influenced the lyrics of the songs that are considered heavy metal. While it may seem evil or a form of protest it is really up to interpretation over whether or not Heavy Metal is considered wicked and connected to the devil.<ref name=":0">Balmain, Collette. Drawmer, Lois (2009) Something Wicked This Way Comes. <nowiki>http://mccclib.mccc.edu:2094/lib/mccc/detail.action?docID=10380355&p00=%22something+wicked+this+way+comes%22</nowiki></ref>
==Wickedness and Witches== It is believed that there are four different types of witches that occur within society. First there is the white witch, who is good with herbs and spices. The white witch is considered to be a type of good witch. Then there is the weak influencer. This type of witch uses their power to try to influence others, which can be considered both good and evil.Then there is the type of witch that projects evil onto others. This type of witch is the one that is considered to be wicked. Finally, there is the witch that springs from imagination. Depending on how the person who is imagining the witch sees the witch determines whether this witch is considered good or wicked. Some people speculate that we all are witches in the sense that we all influence people in some way, shape or form.<ref>Scott, E. (1976). Witches: Wise, Weak, or Wicked Women? Journal of Religion and Health, 15(2), 136-139. Retrieved from <nowiki>http://mccclib.mccc.edu:2112/stable/27505341</nowiki></ref>
==Wickedness and Religion== '''Buddhism'''
In the Buddhist religion, those who are wicked are sent to hell. This is typically seen as a Western idea, but it is visible in the Buddhist’s belief. There are 18 different hells and depending on the wicked behavior that is acted out determines which hell you will go to.
In the first hell whatever wicked behavior you have committed will be punished by forced nakedness, which is a horrendous punishment.
In the Burning Cauldron hell, those who have cooked meat are placed there.
In the Hell of Feces and Filth those who have eaten meat are detained here.
In the Hell of Cutting and Grinding if the person committed an act of taking a life they are placed here.
In the Freezing Hell those who did not keep feast days, didn’t do good deeds or didn’t follow the Buddhist way are placed here.<ref name=":0" />

'''William Thomas Valerio Fontaine''' (born '''William Thomas Fontaine'''; December 2, 1909 – December 29, 1968) was an [[United States|American]] [[Philosophy|philosopher]]. Teaching at the [[University of Pennsylvania]] from 1947 to 1967, he was an American Professor of philosophy in the [[Ivy League]]. He was [[African American]] and advocated for African American rights.<ref>{{Cite book | last = Kuklick | first = Bruce | author-link = | last2 = | first2 = | author2-link = | title = Black Philosopher, White Academy: The Career of William Fontaine | place = Philadelphia | publisher = University of Pennsylvania Press | year = 2008 | volume = | edition = | url = | doi = | id = | isbn = 978-0-8122-4098-6 | postscript = <!--None-->}}</ref>
== Early life and career == Fontaine was born in [[Chester, Pennsylvania|Chester]], [[Pennsylvania]], an industrial town southwest of [[Philadelphia]]. His father worked in a steel mill on the [[Delaware River]]. Enrolling in [[Chester High School (Chester, Pennsylvania)|Chester High School]] at the age of 12, Fontaine graduated in the top third of his class. After his parents died in the 1930s, his aunt raised his younger siblings and funded their continued education.
In 1926 Fontaine enrolled in [[Lincoln University (Pennsylvania)|Lincoln University]], a school about 30 miles west of Chester. He wrote poems and analytic essays for the school newspaper, in which he argued that African Americans needed to show "ability, aggressiveness, and cooperation" to succeed. He graduated first in his class in 1930.
Over the next six years, Fontaine taught Latin, history and government at Lincoln. He also pursued an [[Master of Arts|M.A.]] in Philosophy from the nearby University of Pennsylvania, which he earned in 1932. He earned his [[Doctor of Philosophy|Ph.D.]] in Philosophy from Penn in 1936.
He worked as a professor of philosophy and history at [[Southern University]] in Louisiana from 1936 to 1942. Fontaine married an acquaintance from Philadelphia in 1936, Willabelle Hatton of [[Iva, South Carolina]]; they had two daughters, Jean and Vivian.
Fontaine returned to Penn in 1943 and audited graduate courses until 1946. Drafted during [[World War II]], he worked at [[Fort Holabird|Holabird Signal Depot]] in [[Baltimore]], [[Maryland]]. He taught basic education to illiterate soldiers.
Fontaine joined the University of Pennsylvania faculty in 1947 as a lecturer and was promoted to Assistant Professor two years later.
==Philosophy== Influenced by [[emotivism|emotivist]] philosopher [[Charles Leslie Stevenson|C. L. Stevenson]], Fontaine called his own position a "modified ethical [[relativism]]". When a group desired a certain state of affairs, he argued, it might alter the attitudes fundamental to its ethical stance. For example, politicians offered employment to blacks during [[World War I]] not in order to achieve occupational racial equality, but to avert defeat by Germany. Blacks may not have been as interested in the latter, but they certainly were in the better jobs.
==Political views== Raised in an unusually [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic]] household in Chester, Fontaine was a strong supporter of the [[New Deal]]. During the [[Harry S. Truman|Truman]] and later [[Joseph McCarthy|McCarthy]] eras, Fontaine supported the presidential candidacy of socially liberal [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]] [[Governor of Minnesota|governor]] [[Harold Stassen]], who served as President of Penn from 1948 to 1953.
Fontaine was considerably more opposed to [[Communism]] than even to the [[racism]] in some Western democracies. As a result, he became a liberal [[Internationalism (politics)|internationalist]] during the [[Cold War]]. He supported Presidents Truman, [[Dwight D. Eisenhower|Eisenhower]], and [[John F. Kennedy|Kennedy]] in their anti-Communist agendas. At the same time, he strongly supported the growing [[Civil Rights Movement (1955–1968)|Civil Rights]] movement.
Fontaine expounded his civil rights views in ''Reflections on Segregation, Desegregation, Power, and Morals'', published in 1967. While he supported racial equality, he argued that the growing [[Black Power]] movement contained the same intellectual defects that existed in white racism, in that it sought preferential treatment for blacks and the non-participation of whites in black life. Considered too unfocused by contemporaries, the text received no reviews until 40 years after its publication.
==Later life, travels, and Penn career== Fontaine was diagnosed with [[tuberculosis]] in 1949. After working only one half-time and two years of medical leave, he returned to his normal Penn position in 1955. He received an assistant professorship in 1956, tenure in 1957, and an associate professorship in 1963.
Interested in growing [[African nationalism]] in the era of [[decolonization]], Fontaine traveled worldwide to discuss [[Pan-Africanism|Pan-African]] issues. In 1959, he attended [[Pope John XXIII]]’s address of thanks to those who promoted black culture. The next year, he traveled to [[Lagos]], [[Nigeria]], where he celebrated the inauguration of his classmate, [[Nnamdi Azikiwe]] as [[List of Governors-General of Nigeria|Governor General]]. Two years later, as secretary of the [[American Society of African Culture]], he attended a conference on [[socialism]] called by [[Senegal]]ese [[List of Presidents of Senegal|President]] [[Léopold Sédar Senghor]].
With the worsening of his tuberculosis, Fontaine finished ''Reflections'' in 1967 and went on indefinite medical leave. After being confined to an apartment for more than a year, he died on December 29, 1968.
==Legacy== In his honor, the University of Pennsylvania established the Fontaine Fellowships in 1970, awarded to "provide the additional funds necessary to students from underrepresented minority groups to pursue full-time doctoral study".<ref>[http://www.archives.upenn.edu/people/1900s/fontaine_wm_t_v.html "William Thomas Valeria Fontaine (1909-1968)"], Penn Biographies, University Archives & Record Center.</ref>
